item.title: Ex-Ubisoft Designer Pushes Back Against â€˜Online Conspiracy Theoriesâ€™
item.content:encoded:
A former Ubisoft developer has hit back at â€œonline conspiracy theoriesâ€ that blame the French publisherâ€™s ever-falling stock valuation and game development struggles  on â€œDEI.â€ Instead, he says the problems arise from â€œBig Business Syndrome.â€

As translated by Automaton, ex-Ubisoft Osaka game designer Kensuke Shimoda shared his pushback on X in response to a comic by manga artist Sadataro attributing Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadowsâ€™ sales performance to Ubisoftâ€™s â€œDEIâ€ initiatives. For context, Ubisoft has previously stated that Assassinâ€™s Creed Shadows â€œperformed within expectations,â€ and, as of July 2025, had amassed over 5 million players.

Ever since Shadows dared include an African samurai as one of its two protagonists, itâ€™s been the target of anti-woke attacks, including from Elon Musk (who was later ratioâ€™d by whoever runs the official Assassinâ€™s Creed X account). Some of those same people have now been saying the companyâ€™s financial fallout vindicates their attacks on diversity and inclusion in gaming.

Shimoda, who worked for the publisher from 2021 to 2024, stated â€œunequivocallyâ€ that Ubisoftâ€™s DEI initiatives â€œdidnâ€™t wield that much influenceâ€ and were, in fact, â€œactually beneficialâ€ in helping them expand in South America and the Middle Eastern territories.

His comments regarding Ubisoftâ€™s â€œexcessively low turnover rateâ€ and â€œlack of senior/lead-level staff with experienceâ€ imply that Shimoda lays the blame squarely at the feet of the publisherâ€™s upper management, especially when paired with his â€œBig Business Syndromeâ€ remark.

Big Business Syndrome is a term coined by Kazuma Tateisi, former president of Japanese electronic manufacturer OMRON, in 1987. In short, Tateisi believed that the profits of several prominent Japanese companies in the 80s began to fall once their leaders became too obsessed with maintaining the status quo. When stepping down as president in 1987, Tateisi warned OMRON employees that refusing to pursue the same riskier strategies that led to their initial success, yet continuing to expand in the process, would lead to them suffering the same fate as their contemporaries.

Shimoda is arguing that Ubisoft has become a victim of the same mentality. On January 21, the publisher announced a painful shakeup that included the cancellation of â€œ4 unannounced titles, including 3 new IPâ€™sâ€ and the formation of â€œFive Creative Housesâ€ that will solely focus on developing games for their pre-existing IPs. But some current employees feel like this latest reset is just history repeating itself.

item.title: I Have A Resident Evil Requiem Theory, And I Hope Iâ€™m Wrong
item.content:encoded:
I played about three hours of Resident Evil Requiem earlier this month, and I could not shake the feeling that I know where the rest of the game is going to go when it launches next month. Though I have not seen enough of the ninth entry in Capcomâ€™s long-running horror series to be sure, Iâ€™ve got a theory, and itâ€™s one that some fans have independently come to as well after combing through the trailers. Thereâ€™s nothing in the time I played that outright confirms this is the way things are going to go, but there are clues that Iâ€™ve started latching onto. If you donâ€™t want your experience of Requiem to be influenced even by speculation about where the story might go, turn back now.

I think Leon Scott Kennedy, one of Resident Evilâ€™s long-time protagonists, is going to be dead by the end of Resident Evil Requiem. Now, I know what youâ€™re thinking. â€œCapcom would never kill one of Resident Evilâ€™s recurring leads.â€ And yeah, we are in uncharted territory. Take my hand and follow me down this dark passageway toward the worst-case scenario. 

In my time playing Requiem, I learned something that astute fans have already picked up on: Leon has some kind of deadly infection. Heâ€™s looking for a cure, which is why he ends up in the Rhodes Hill Chronic Care Center where his Requiem co-lead Grace Ashcroft has been taken. The infection manifests in a gnarly wound on his neck, but whateverâ€™s going on, he still has time before he turns. How much time? Thatâ€™s unclear right now. But that infection is only half the reason I think Leon is going to be pushing daisies by the end of Requiem.

The gameâ€™s name, Requiem, has a few different meanings, both in and out of the context of the game. A requiem, as the dictionary describes it, is a â€œmass for the dead,â€ or some kind of musical tribute to the dead. Yes, this could be in reference to Graceâ€™s mother Alyssa Ashcroft, whose death is an inciting incident in the story, but it also has a very specific meaning attached to it that links Leon and Grace. Early on in the section I played, Leon and Grace meet, and the ex-Raccoon City cop gives Grace a powerful revolver named Requiem. Though I only had one bullet for it in Graceâ€™s resource-scarce segment, it did blow a hole right through a zombieâ€™s head, so thank you, Leon, for saving my ass with your gift of foresight. However, this moment could also be seen as a literal passing of the torch (or gun) to a new generation of Resident Evil heroes, and thatâ€™s something Capcom has been pretty upfront about in its marketing. 

Two generations of survival. Grace Ashcroft and Leon S. Kennedy face unimaginable terrors in Resident Evil Requiem.

Graceâ€™s playstyle is defined by her inexperience. A gun that wrecks shop in Leonâ€™s hand barely harms a zombie when Grace is using it. This is her origin story, and while she and Leon might be separated for large parts of the game, she has his gun, whose name literally means a tribute to the dead, on her at all times. From a thematic standpoint, Leon entrusts something to her, and parts from her fully realizing he may never see her or the revolver again. I would not be surprised if Requiem ended with Leon doing something to save Grace, ensuring she gets out of this whole outbreak alive and earning himself a big goddamn heroâ€™s sacrifice, knowing that he was on borrowed time anyway. Grace escapes, but still has the Requiem revolver in hand, and uses it as a tribute to her fallen comrade in future cases. See? It all comes full circle.

Thatâ€™s all speculation, but if Requiem is really meant to be a generational shift for Resident Evil, it would make a lot of sense for Capcom to sell that in the most definitive way possible. But hey, characters like Leon, Chris, and Jill have gotten through worse, so I also wouldnâ€™t be surprised if he manages to squeeze his way out of this problem, too. Weâ€™ll find out for sure when Resident Evil Requiem launches on February 27.
